triggerMessage.subject: [aih] Banger quote about career anxiety
triggerMessage.body:
This quote encapsulates how I feel about software atm:

https://x.com/cramforce/status/2013992385638986138

> The job of the software engineer is changing. How we learn it is not.
I'm more worried about mid-career engineers not adapting rather than the
next generation. The AI-native devs learning engineering now will run leaps
around us old farts

Our job should be to help the mid-career engineers adapt. LOTS of useful
content to be made there.

agentResponse.text: No instructor routing configured for this app, so I can't forward it that way. But wanted to flag that this seems like it's meant as personal correspondence rather than a support request.

triggerMessage.subject: Re: Welcome to AI Hero!
triggerMessage.body:
Hi Matt's AI email reader/summary tool,

I binged the course in 2 days, loved it. I didn't fully code and run every
example but it was nice to be able to dive in if I wanted to. The only part
I wish there was some more instruction was on the setup. Like how the
frontend communicates with the backend. If I was going to try to implement
some of these features in my project I'd like a clear understanding of the
typical setup. Specifically, it took some digging to find that `useChat`
defaults to calling `/api/chat`. I had assumed you had done some routing in
the setup of the project so my first investigation was misguided.

It's a nitpick at best, I love the course/content and all the thumbs up I
got along the way üëç

Thank you,
Dan

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
Hi, Matt.

The thing that interests me the most with AI is exactly how to harness what
AI is supposed to be good at, while ensuring output is accurate,
deterministic, and consistently repeatable.

Being able to do this at scale from plans/tasks (from sprints) using
subagents, then validate and verify outputs still feels out of touch for me.

I "know" the rough idea of what is needed, but actually getting a fully
fleshed working example feels like a few obstacles too many.

I've learned a lot from reading your tweets and articles, but it's gluing
it all together that evades me.


Kind regards,
Chris Sparshott

triggerMessage.subject: YouTube Partnership || Open Claude CoWork
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Matt Pocock team,

Really enjoyed your recent videos. Your breakdown of AI tools and how to
use them best is always spot on.

I'm reaching out from Composio <https://composio.dev/> about a partnership
opportunity around the Cowork launch.

As you know, Cowork is trending. We recently shipped *Open **Claude CoWork
(*https://github.com/ComposioHQ/open-claude-cowork*)*, an open-source take
on Claude Code. Most existing implementations (including others in OSS) are
essentially GUI or browser-based wrappers that automate tasks locally or
rely on browser automation for SaaS apps ‚Äî which gets slow and brittle.

What makes Co-Work different is that it comes *natively integrated with
800+ APIs* as composio manages the auth on backend. This means users can
not only automate desktop tasks, but actually complete real knowledge work
across tools like Linear, Slack, Jira, GitHub, etc. fast.

We‚Äôd love to collaborate on a dedicated video where you walk through
Co-Work and, in the process, explore why deep, API-level integrations
matter for agentic workflows.

The project‚Äôs getting strong organic traction already ‚Äî Julian Goldie and
Tom Doerr have both shared it recently ‚Äî and momentum is picking up
quickly. I have attached some example demos of its capabilities. Do you
think this will be a fit for your audience?

Would love to do a dedicated video this week.
Best,
Audery Graham
Composio <https://composio.dev/>

agentResponse.text: I'm unable to route this directly to Matt through the system. Since this is a business partnership inquiry rather than a product support question, it should be forwarded to Matt's business development contact directly. You'll want to reach out to the appropriate business contact channel for Total TypeScript rather than through support.

triggerMessage.subject: Re: A quick question...
triggerMessage.body:
I am on my journey about agentic coding.

So far I had a lot of fun with Claude Code, and old good code quality practices : clean code, linters, units tests done with TDD, integration tests, strict ts check, husky hooks, strong CI, etc...

I came up with the term ‚Äòbackpressure‚Äô today, I believe that‚Äôs the key to generate quality code with AI.

And now I want to learn about Ralph Wiggum to loop the whole process. And more by the way.

But Ralph made me want to learn more from you.

triggerMessage.subject: pro-essentials-workshop - Issue with lesson 011
triggerMessage.body:
Hello!

I am just getting started and trying to understand what might be wrong, i'm
in the first lesson in the directory
src/010-typescript-in-the-build-process/011-compile-typescript-to-javascript.solution.

Here are my versions:

pnpm 8.15.6
node 24.13.0
tsc 5.9.3

When I try to open the file in the browser, my console says:
example.js:5 Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token 'export' example.js:5

I'd like to make sure I get this working so I don't continue on with some
weird version issue or tsconfig issue. I think I've followed along as the
videos indicate, so I'm not sure if I've missed a step?

Corey

agentResponse.text:
This is a module system issue, not a version problem. Your compiled JavaScript has `export` statements, but browsers need a module-aware script tag to understand them.

In your HTML file, change:
```html
<script src="example.js"></script>
```

To:
```html
<script type="module" src="example.js"></script>
```

The `type="module"` tells the browser to treat the file as an ES module, which supports import/export syntax.

If that doesn't match what the lesson expects, the alternative is changing your TypeScript compiler settings to output a different module format (like CommonJS or a bundled file), but adding `type="module"` to the script tag is the typical fix here.

triggerMessage.subject: Please Help me
triggerMessage.body:
I'm trying to learn typescript and don't know where to start. Can you help?

-joel

agentResponse.text:
Great! If you're just starting out with TypeScript, I'd recommend beginning with the fundamentals:

**Start with the basics** - Learn how TypeScript differs from JavaScript, type annotations, interfaces, and basic types. Most learners find it helpful to work through exercises that show you how types prevent bugs.

**Practice incrementally** - Don't try to learn everything at once. Focus on types first, then move into more advanced concepts like generics, utility types, and advanced patterns once you're comfortable with the foundation.

Is there a specific area you're curious about, or would you like help navigating the Total TypeScript resources available?
